name: Buff Smoothie
headline: Buff Smoothie
keywords: Healthy Breakfast,Breakfast,Healthy,Healthy Brunch Recipes,Brunch,Fruit,Pomegranate Recipes,Diabetes-Friendly,Low-Fat,Low Sodium,Heart-Healthy,Low-Cholesterol,Gluten Free,Low Calorie,High Fiber
recipeIngredient: 4 ounces acai, grape, or pomegranate juice

recipeInstructions.text: Combine the soy milk, juice, banana, strawberries, blueberries, and the peaches in the carafe of a blender. Cover and refrigerate overnight or up to 8 hours.

In the morning, or when the fruit is partially thawed, put the carafe on the base of the blender, start at the lowest speed and slowly accelerate to medium, until you achieve a vortex. Blend on medium for 1 minute. Increase the speed to high and blend for an additional minute. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: You would never know there is no sugar in this!  It‚Äôs plenty sweet and also filling.  Perfect smoothie!
Delicious üòã¬†
Great
delicious and healthy! that‚Äôs a hard combo to nail. will be making these weekly!
Yum. whats that?
This is a great way to start the day!
Added fresh banana instead.. worked very well
Love this smoothie every morning, but...why does the recipe say 3 servings? It's 24 ounces of ingredients, and the video looks single-serving. What am I missing?
I can't ¬†wait ¬†to ¬†try out ¬†these recipes ¬†

This came out great. I especially like the tip about using frozen items but leaving in the fridge overnight! Texture comes out perfect.

One note though: It says it makes 3 24 ounce servings and that's incorrect. It makes 1 24 oz serving. The nutrition though is divided by 3 since I would say this recipe runs in the 300 calorie range if you drank all 24 ounces.
Make these all the time! We use a variety of fruit and juices. I like to add yogurt too! Very refreshing treat that the whole family enjoys.

I love this smoothie recipe, it is great way to start the day.  When I first started making them I had one issue I am a caffeine junkie.  Having this smoothie and coffee is just too much liquid for me to productive so I made one small addition to the recipe.  I warm the soy milk in the microwave and steep it with chai tea.  This has proved to be a great benefit, the chai adds some nice spice that goes well with the pomegranate juice and the banana and it add the bit of caffeine my body needs to be functional in the morning.

This smoothie is fantastic. I substitute almond milk and add 1 T of sprouted chia powder (you can't even taste it for added omega 3-s, protein and fiber. Also, being female I reduce the portion size slightly by using between 2.5-3 oz. of each ingredient instead of 4 oz. Kind of a lot of sugar for the a.m. but at least it's natural sugar. A great starter recipe that lends itself to many substitutions and additions. I also like adding baby spinach and/or wheat germ for even more health benefits. Thanks Alton! Like other reviewers, I'd like to see more of your healthy recipes on Food Network or in a book!
Tip-if your scale doesn't have a tare function, weigh ingredients individually on scale inside a light weight measuring cup adding to blender between measurements

Quite delicious!  Perfect for almost every morning for kick-start of day with different fruits for variety and taste.  Thank you for this recipe.  Could you please show the four lists of what to eat   on daily, weekly, monthly basis as you lost the 50 lbs.  You showed them in great color and they were so easy to understand and follow, but too fast to get them written down.  Thank you  -  love your show!

Since my teen years, I have not been able to eat breakfast until late in the morning; doing so would result in feeling ill for most of the day. I decided to give this recipe a try in lieu of skipping food until lunch and using caffeine as a way to suppress hunger. I am happy to say, this has made a tremendously positive impact on my diet and overall well being. Ingredients are readily available and the recipe is flexible to allow for seasonal fruit interchanges as well. I try to kick in spinach as well for an added vitamin punch.

Thanks to AB and the Crew!
Got one fruit serving down before I'm out of my PJ's! Thanks AB!

Yum!  Had this for breakfast yesterday.  I don't care for soy milk, so I used coconut milk instead.  I also added a scoop of whey protein powder.  I skipped allowing it to partially thaw overnight in the fridge, and my blender blasted it into creamy, ice-cream like smoothness.  Will definitely be making this one again, (and again, and again.

This is so Decadent.  I did however make some changes but not enough to change the flavor much.  I didn't have soy milk to used nonfat organic milk in it's place.  Also didn't have frozen peaches so I used 4 oz. of sliced apple(with the skin on.  I also added 2 Tbs of flax seed. It was wonderful and healthy!!  I froze the leftovers so I can try it as a dessert as he recommended.

Excellent. I feel great doing this for breakfast. I've been making these for a few months now and I also mix it up a bit based on what's on hand. The basic idea has so many options.

Thank You Alton for giving me a go-to breakfast!
Mighty good! Worked well with rice milk over here... Thanks.  -- Davis Katlaps
Awesome smoothie! you might try frozen Mango if you can't get peaches. I add 1 scoop of protein powder (Whey if it is a gym day, it is great!
I add 2 handfuls of spinach to this and make a green smoothie - you cannot taste the spinach, and it is awesome!
Best smoothie I've tried - love it!  I subbed in blackberries for strawberries because that's what we had in the fridge...tasted great!
Thick and delicious. I'll be having one of these tomorrow morning as well.
Awesome.  Although there is plenty of insoluble fiber, I added 2 Tbls Benefiber for added soluble fiber.
Great smoothie recipe.  Key is to be sure you use at least one frozen fruit (I prefer bannana) if evrything else is fresh.  I also use a scoop of sugar free whey protein powder.

Delicious! The best smoothie I ever made. One recommendation: you should definitely try vanilla almond milk [preferably Almond Breeze] instead of soy milk. It adds a little extra flavor and sweetness. I used some V8 Fusion Acai Mixed Berry Juice, but I'd also recommend the pomegranate juice to give it some tartness.

Excellent smoothie, sweet but not too sweet, and very filling. I substituted mango for the peaches. For those who say they don't like soy milk, give it a try anyway; it's not like you taste it in this smoothie anyway.

This is a great formula that I use every morning for my breakfast, thanks to Alton Brown.  I use any combination of 8 oz of liquids (milk, juices, yogurt, etc) and 16 oz of frozen fruit.  A kitchen scale with a tare function makes this a snap, even in my sleepy daze first thing in the morning!
My husband doesn't like smoothies.  He loves this one.  It is inexpensive and quickly made as well as nourishing.  Holds me over until lunch time without that hungry feeling.
I put whey protein and a pinch of orange juice. Along with the other ingredients, this makes it a great drink to have before a workout.

I make mine this way but if you use a Ninja (chops ice easily) you don't need to let it sit overnight. I use Greek yogurt w 14 gr protein. I make less, single servings, and let it sit for about 10 minutes before pulsing. Sometimes it is too thick if you use completely frozen fruit so I might try this way tho, so it's completely ready to go first thing in the morning. You can also freeze your yogurt if it's close to expiring or if you need an ice ingredient the same way as a frozen fruit.

Excellent smoothie! For me, we use 3/4 of the recipe.  I can't be bothered with a lot of individual bags, just grab a nice mixed pineapple/papaya/mango/strawberry and blackberries for me fruit component.  We use half non-fat milk, half good quality greek yogurt. The calories are the same, the texture is awesome and the healthy fat and protein are good for long term energy use.  Then personally I like a pomegranate/cranberry or pomegranate/cherry (really high in potassium) mix that I found in my frozen juice isle.

Thank you Alton! This is a terrific smoothie and my go to recipe for breakfast.  I make it with 5 ounces of each ingredient and it makes a generous portion for me and my husband. We're satisfied and full until lunch.  I use low fat vanilla soy milk instead of plain.  We've also used both pomegranate juice and a blueberry/acai juice. It's great using either kind of juice.
I love the smoothie as written and make it often. I made the mistake of changing it up this morning by using strawberries, blackberries and raspberries. I'm still picking seeds out of my teeth, lol.

@Wayneg32 -- Acai is a berry from the Acai Palm.  It looks a little bit like a small purple grape.  The juice can usually be found in either the juice aisle or in the organic/health food section of most grocery stores.  If you can't find it there, try a health food specialty store.  As an alternative, I've read others have used V8 Fusion juices with this recipe with success.  I've never tried substitutions myself so can't testify to the taste.
The recipe sounds great but, what is acacia grape juice and where in a grocery store can I find it?  Thank you for your assistance.
Very tasty! I was expecting to taste the soy milk, which I'm not a big fan of, but to my surprise this smoothie tastes like mixed berries and is very delicious.

My husband and I are working on getting into better shape/healthier and tried this recipe this morning. Tasted great! We are also going to change out some of the fruits to help keep it interesting, and to use yogurt sometimes instead of only soy.Love Alton! Some of our fav. recipes are his shepards pie and cassorle dishes. We always check his info first!
Oh, it was about $27 for us for almost two weeks worth for two people, including the yogurt and extra frozen fruits.

I had been wondering for the longest how he lost his weight. I was so angry with myself that I missed that episode(I watch his show all the time). Now I'm angry at the network for not planning to  re-air it. THANK YOU mathgeek123 for your research!.I, for one, am very grateful!

I was looking for his lists too. I found this on another site.
Daily
- Fruits
- Whole Grains
- Leafy Greens

- Green Tea

- Oily Fish

- Pasta
- Dessert

NEVER!
- Fast Food
- Soda
- Processed meals/frozen dinners
- Canned soup
- ‚ÄúDiet‚Äù anything

PLUS: Eat breakfast every day, no exceptions.

I just watched this episode and I didn't get a chance to write down what each of his groups had for foods! can someone help??

THANKS!!

meagandees@gmail.com

Good smoothie except for the soy milk. I would use a nut or seed milk. Almond, sesame, etc.
Soy is not so good for people.
http://www.soyonlineservice.co.nz/
http://www.naturalhealthstrategies.com/dangers-of-soy.html
http://hiddensoy.com/
http://www.shirleys-wellness-cafe.com/soy.htm

the recipe is good (i like vanilla soy milk personally, or almond) but i just wanted to address the comment about the negative health benefits of soy (although i do intend to try some yogurt in my smoothie anyway, because i like yogurt and think it will taste good in here, and it adds the probiotic benefit, if there's any truth to that, but it has nothing to do with the soy).

the studies that show a negative benefit to a high-soy diet, typically look at *denatured* soy, like you find in meat replacement products like "veggie" burgers (TVP or TSP) or in powdered soy. Studies that have looked into low-processed soy products like soy milk or tofu (or tempeh) generally find overwhelmingly positive results. it's just that the outlets that report on this don't always clearly distinguish that, and you get a headline like "soy is bad for you" but soy and "textured soy protein" aren't necessarily the same thing when it comes to how your body handles them.

bottom line: soy milk is good for you.

My husband & I love this smoothie!!
Haven't found one that we like better.

This is the second recipe I've reviewed from this episode and, unlike the other one, I love it! (Probably because it doesn't have sardines in it, a sardine smoothie... no.)

I used fat free greek style yogurt rather than soy, since I don't like soy and don't have any lactose problems, and keeping yogurt around doesn't make me crave cookies :)

Anyway, this is an excellent recipe! I encourage everyone to try it and to experiment with various fruits!
The best way to start a day!!

I use plain yogurt instead of soy, because it helps the thickness, plus, if you read Men's Health, or some of the other places it has been published, soy may have some detrimental effects that make it not worth it.

As for nutrition, unless you are using fresh berries, everything except the banana is labeled, and I bet it is not hard to figure out the nutrients for that.

I found a cups to weight by ingredient website and realized I had the measurements all wrong. Thought it may help some others.

4 oz Blueberries = 1 c.
4 oz Peaches = 1/2 c.
4 oz Strawberries (halved/sliced) = 4/7 c.

http://www.recipes4us.co.uk/us_cups_to_weight.htm#B

For you folks that find the full 24 oz of this smoothie doesn't last till lunch I would like to suggest a couple things. First don't switch to moo milk instead of soy milk. Soy has more protein and other "good stuff" over moo milk. Worse than that is switching out to low fat milk, fat is energy to burn. If you are using Soy milk and still burn through 24 oz to soon, beef things up with protein powder, that's what I do. You could toss in a egg (yes raw) instead of the powder. With all the acid in there from the berries I don't worry much about catching any thing from the eggs. Salute!

Like most of his recipes, this works really well if you look at it as a formula instead of just a single recipe. With this in mind, I've used it for a wide variety of smoothie variations and have enjoyed all of them.

I've never made it with soy milk (I'm not a fan) but have tried it with milk and then with kefir (sort of like thin yoghurt).

My only problem is I tend not to find it very filling. I love it and enjoy them but they feel more like a snack than something I can have for breakfast. I end up needing to pair it with an egg to last me through the morning.
My doctor recommended  a low-carb diet. I use this basic recipe a a base and use frozen mixed fruit and a banana. I also substitute 2% milk. For juice I use Healthy Choice brand a

This smoothie is EXCELLENT!  I made it as written except that I used almond milk (thanks to the other reviewers here for the suggestion!) because I don't do soy.  The portion is large so I split mine with my kids and they love it too!  The one thing I would like is if AB would print the nutritional information for his new "healthy" Good Eats.

Very easy to make, and easy to make alterations.

I found an acai/blueberry juice, so I substituted frozen blackberries for the blueberries--still very "purple", to be sure. (The only problem with this is the seeds, but they don't bother me that much). I also use vanilla flavored soy milk. I've also taken to putting a fiber supplement before blending.

I don't want to get my blender out every morning, or leave it out taking up counter space, so I just use my immersion blender and essentially follow the same directions. The consistency is probably a bit off from what it SHOULD be, but still tastes good. It has become a frequent breakfast for me. It keeps me satisfied until lunch (and feeling better about myself, because it's so healthy).

Life changing show to me. I now have a smoothie every morning!
I don't remember what you had for dinner. Can you post the 4 food groups and what to have always, occasionally and rarely and never on your website? Please show this program again and again, for I want to save it to review and take notes. This was a very important show for all of us who want to eat well. Caroline

I am preparing each  of these recipes from "Live and Let Diet", I already know we will love them just because I have never been disapointed with AB's recipes. We need MORE episodes of Good Eats like this one. Come on AB I know you can give us more! PS; When can we expect a new Book for this one? I have already been looking for it...

Tried this recipe a few weeks ago after seeing ABs 'diet' episode. It's been my breakfast ever since! Just Love It! Now I'm not a smoothie fan at all! Always thought of them as much too sweet. Yet it is so easy, to prepare the night before then give it a few spins in the blender the next morning. My blender is an inexpensive Cuisinart, I use the pulse mode to break the fruit up then spin away as AB recommends. Comes out thick, smooth, and creamy.

Like a few, who've already commented, I too substituted milk due a soy allergy. Use fresh banana as I couldn't find frozen at my grocery store. Also I divide the smoothie between 2 mornings as it way too much for me. So far I haven't experienced any problems with the smoothie not being as good the next morning.

Should AB publish the recipes he used for his weight loss I'd be in line to purchase them. I understand his categories, but I'm no chef or nutritionist so a bit of guidance and lots of meal ideas would be extremely helpful too me.

I tried this with just some things that I had in my house.  I don't really like milk, so I used vanilla flavored almond milk instead.  It's in the organic section usually.  It adds protein also.  This smoothie is very easy to make.  I'm not an early riser yet I can get this made in no time.  I also like that it doesn't have yogurt.  I hate yogurt.  Great recipe!

I've been behind on my Good Eats watching and was a little taken aback when I saw Alton earlier in the week wearing a long sleeve shirt and looking skinny. I was concerned. Turns out, I didn't have to be. When I watched the episode from a night or two later and he explained what he was doing. And I was relieved.

My wife and I cannot wait to try this recipe. Like Terry in Kaplan, we have the Ninja Pro, which my wife uses to make slushes and smoothies (and crushed ice for her beverages) so that'll be our mixer. We'll be picking up the ingredients this week (we'll visit the membership warehouses near us for the IQF packages) and it looks like we'll need to buy a box of drinking straws.

I guess I won't be needing my morning bagel any more.

Thank you, Alton, for this recipe. And thanks to everyone that posted alternatives for some ingredients.
We're 11 year old twin boys and we made this smoothie for the first time today.  It's really good!

I am not allergic to soy, however, its not a fav in my diet.  I use a protein powder purchased from like GNC to add to my smoothies.  I find the vanilla adds a nice touch to it without overpowering the fruit.  Add the desired amount until you get the taste/protein amount you desire.  Good drinking....

I am always looking for great smoothie recipes. I think this one is probably the best and heathiest. I admire Alton's "make over" since he began his new life-stlye eating! Let me know when he gets all his healthy recipes together in a book, for I'm am ready to buy it! Success to him for taking a stand against some of the things we have been traditionally consuming.

I work so early in the morning with special ed kids (by 6:30 I'm on the bus picking them up to take them to high school) that breakfast just doesn't work much for me unless it is pre-packaged! YUCK! I've had a LOT of health issues this school year and I've dragged with my tail down all winter. I've been looking for a really good smoothie recipe to take along on the bus to boost my metabolism and help me lose unwanted pounds. THIS IS IT! Thank you, Alton!

Also, since I volunteer and go to church on Sunday's so early (music practice at 7:30 am!), this is also going along with me on Sundays. And while everyone else at Grace Methodist is having the usual donut, I'm gonna be sucking down something far more yummy! LOL So full of everything I need to get going in a much healthier way!

praze10

I want to thank Alton for his wonderful display in applying his ability to break nutritional values down so that you can understand how to go about eating the right foods and combinations.  Also I must say he looks great!  I always enjoy his shows, but Episode: Live and Let Eat was excellent.  I knowhe must have received some heat from the dairy associaton for expressing that he does not consume milk and preferrs soy milk.  I respect that he did it anyway.   All you have to do is look at Alton, he looks great!  What he is doing works and I am so impressed. He has a quick wit and the knowledge to back up what he says.  I really enjoy Good Eats and now I respect Alton even more!  Thank you for telling it like it is!
I have an allergy to soy so what else can I use to increase protein in the smoothie?

Just want to say Thank You for inspiring me to work towards a healthier diet. I started by making my first Smoothie and have gone on from there. I do, however, substitute steamed sweet potato for the banana since I don't care for banana. The sweet potato adds a lot of flavor and fiber. I also add a tablespoon or two of ground flax seed. The flax is great for your body and helps keep the leftovers nice and thick. Let me know when your Healthy Cook Book is coming out as I'm looking forward to it.

Made this recipe to test it out before committing to an everyday breakfast... this thing is SO filling I could not have the whole thing, put about a third in the freezer to enjoy later. Followed recipe as instructed, used Pom juice and frozen mango chunks in place of the peaches (not a fan of peaches) This is a great smoothie!!! look forward to replacing my cereal int he mornings!

I made this last night to have for breakfast.  I had to buy a blender to make it, so I was hoping it would work out.  It definitely did!  I drank it at 6 before work and made it all the way past noon without feeling hungry.  I put kiwi in mine, it was really awesome.  Highly recommend.

I made this smoothie this morning and it was fantastic. Many are right that you have to drink it slow. Only had banana and blueberries and it still was great. I also used skim milk. Only think I've noticed was the blender..I used the ninja pro and handled everything in four or five spins without any problem and did not have to place in frig night before. Will have this every morning from now on!

I was influenced by a sale and coupon offer from my local Publix store to purchase Silk brand almond milk in lieu of soy. I hope Alton will endorse the substitution as the result is, most likely, equally delicious.

I also hope Alton is authoring a new 'Buff Brown' cookbook. Please put me on the list for six advance copies!

this smoothie is awesome!!!!  i used low fat vanilla soy milk and plum smart juice and the recommended fruit and it is my new favorite breakfast!  it is very filling and so easy to make.  i throw everything together at night and blend it up in the morning and i'm satisfied till lunch.  thanks for another great recipe alton!!

Needed a change of pace for my breakfast routine.  Trying to cut out bread/cereals/starches.  Prepped this the night before, as suggested (and b/c I don't like to get up and earlier than necessary!).  Used 1 tbsp non-fat plain greek yogurt, 1 oz Mona-Vie Acai blend, 2 oz Cran-Pom juice, handful frozen strawberries, 2 handfuls frozen blueberries, 1 frozen mini banana, 1 cup light vanilla Silk (soymilk).  This morning, blended for 1 minute...DELISH!!!!!!  Kept me satiated too!!!!!!!   (I'm normally starving by 1030am when I eat my usual egg whites, or cereal.)

This recipe is very similar to what I have been making for some time, but I first put dry oatmeal and flax seed in the blender and mix until a powder. Then start adding the wet stuff. Even more nutrition.
...instead of soy milk, and you can completely vary the fruit. Today I used banana, pear, mango and mixed berries. So yummy!

just a few of my changes: I drop the bananas, add V8 Splash pomegranate blueberry, use nonfat milk, don't let the fruit thaw overnight, add 4-8oz of water (to compensate for the non-thawed fruit) and add a scoop of my favorite supplement to it.

this lets me make the shake on my way out the door after finishing my morning workout and "getting ready for work' routine. It isn't "diet" by any means calorie wise (to address a concern brought up by another comment). It does have 300+ calories (the same amount as a burger with all the fixings) but this has what the burger is missing - nutrition. This shake has vitamins, minerals, protein, good carbs, and fiber.

If you want to eat breakfast, have a fast paced lifestyle and want to do a little something to be healthier, this shake is an excellent way to get there!

I love this!  I make a triple batch so I can grab and go in the mornings.  Throw in a couple handfuls of baby spinach for some added nutrition.  You won't even know it is there.  I get my kids to eat spinach this way and they have no clue!

Alton Brown has developed a perfect combination of real fruit sweetness (light sweetness with a natural sour/bitter note instead of processed sugar) but that was also extremely healthy and delicious. Most of all, though, the drink is filling and satisfying. I'd put this up against Jamba Juice not just in health but taste and being filling any day.

Remember, though, to drink this slowly. Don't gulp it all down in a few minutes, but drink it over maybe 20-30 minutes so you remain full longer and don't stretch out your stomach. This should last you from when you wake up until it's time for lunch.

I have made this smoothie almost every morning and it makes me feel satisfied and lasts until lunch. I have made a few changes and additions. I buy a combination of blackberries, blueberries, and red raspberries (they are packaged together.) I also use the bananas, peaches, and strawberries, organic vanilla soy milk, vanilla pro-biotic yogurt, and vanilla whey protein. I buy blueberry pomegranite juice that also contains vegetable juices, similar to V-8 Fusion. I have a Back to Basics smoothie machine that works just fine using frozen fruit (I do not prepare it the night before) and agree with Alton about speed control and the need to develop the vortex. The texture is thick, smooth, and luscious, as long as you don't mind a few seeds from the berries.

I made this with some slight variations. I used 4 oz (1/2 cup) light soy milk, 4 oz (1/2 cup) blueberry flavored acai juice, 8 oz (by weight) frozen mixed berries (strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, blackberries), 4 oz (by weight) frozen peaches, and 3 medium raw bananas. My parents' ancient blender attachment to their all-in-one mixer thing did just fine. Though, I did microwave the frozen fruit for about 1 minute first because I didn't want to wait for it to defrost in my refrigerator.

It came out tasting great, and fast. I plan on pouring it into a to-go cup for a quick on-the-go college breakfast. I love this recipe especially because I am vegan, and not many recipes on Good Eats are vegan-friendly or very adaptable.

I used caloriecount.about.com to figure out the calories, which was 515 for the whole 3.5cup recipe. It's a whole lot of smoothie, probably a good 3 servings for me, so it's actually fairly low-cal and quite filling. Thanks, A.B.!

I don't like all the ingredients in the smoothie but blended together it tastes so good! I used only 1/2 the amount of bananas it calls for because it over powered the taste, it's also better with acai pomegranate juice, it tasted sweeter.

I love smoothies and make them all the time, and this one definitely rocks!  It really does have about 340 calories...some people say that's low, but there's that many calories in a cheeseburger, with condiments!

Hi Everyone,
I see you have posted VitaMax blender. We bought the Viking Blender and got it for $130 online. It's a great blender and it is the one he mentions in his book about Kitchen Tools. It does the same thing...create the vortex and it is very simple to use with the dial switch. No need to spend $500. Try this one! It works GREAT!

I've been having this for breakfast the last few days, and was wondering about the calorie count because it is very filling, and the serving size seems huge (it's a pound of fruit!) I put all the ingredients in an online calorie calculator, and it came up as 340 calories. It has 50% of your RDA of fiber, which is why it's so filling, I suppose. The estimated glycemic load is 24 which is apparently on the high side, for people who are sensitive to that.

It takes a long time to drink, compared to my typical breakfast, but it tastes better too.

A tip: my stand blender couldn't hack this, but my immersion blender did a great job. It's very thick-- plan to use a straw or a spoon.

Would like to know the exact calorie court that it has. Also wonder about taking in that much sugar first thing in the morning. It is natural sugar but still sugar.

24 ounces is a lot to take in but I am guessing he does it so large so it is filling.

Because the machine is so well engineered and it is equipped with a variable speed control... I have concluded that although this smoothie will render quite well in a regular $50 blender, you really do need to fork out the cash if you want your smoothies to become fluffier and more homogeneous. Believe me, there WILL be a huge difference in the texture of your smoothies!
Vita Mix is an expensive blender. I got mine, with the metal canister, at the Goodwill store for $10. It is still going 20 years later. Try looking for one on Ebay.

Who knew something so good for you could taste so great?!  This smoothie is awesome!  In fact, I'm sipping on one right now as I type this.  As some people have mentioned in earlier posts, there's no need to get an expensive blender for this recipe.  As Alton suggested, I let my fruit thaw a little in the fridge over night and my 20 year old blender ate through it with no problem what-so-ever!  Please consider making a "Live and let Diet 2" in the near future Alton!  Now, back to my smoothie!

No problem with the smoothie. Tastes great, easy to make, frozen fruits are wonderful. The problem is with the blender advice on the show.

He supposedly hates expensive unitaskers, but the blender that he recommended on the show is a $500 Vitamix. That's not a great recommendation - and the type that he has (usually) avoided in the past.

I've been enjoying this smoothie every morning for nearly the last two week and think it's great. I make small variations to it every day (different fruit, juice, and sometimes I use real milk) and I half the size (it's rather large as it's written). Still, it's great and like many of you have pointed out, I feel like I have more energy and less craving through the morning.

One suggestion though. I've noticed that the acid in the juice is having ill effect on my milk/soy milk if left over night. It separates, or curdles, or whatever. I'm not sure if it's safe to drink at this point, but it definitively doesn't look like good eats. I add the milk in the morning...seems to work better.

i used Cranberry juice in mine, it was great calories it rounded out to be about 485, which is a pretty solid breakfast, just think if you keep your calories at about 1300 a day and manage to  be active you will lose weight. Stay busy chew gum, choose healthy snacks!
I made this this morning for breakfast, and I stayed full for a long time.  It's so good!  I added pinapple and mango to mine too.  It would be good if you added orange juice.

Not sure about the calories, but this is delicious and filling!

I don't do soy because of some of the gastro issues it causes (gave up milk years ago for alternative choices) so I used my usual, which is Almond drink (milk). Although looking at the nutrition info, it doesn't have the same protein content as soy but it has all the other vitamin additives that soy does (soy milk is fortified just like any other drink we consume). So I modified this recipe to include about 3 or 4 ounces of plain euro style non-fat yoghurt. The extra bite of the plain yoghurt is great and I get my calcium and protein with no additional sugar or fat.

Thanks Alton, love the show. And thanks for the great, HEALTHY, recipes!

Not that this recipe needs yet another great review, but this is so delicious and healthy.  I have made several smoothies in the past and as some have indicated it is easy to toss in frozen fruits with some liquid and possibly some yogurt, but this combination and amounts just appeals to my taste buds and health conscious side so much...bravo Alton!  I too have the Vita Mix and just love that machine for making smoothies actually smooth...blueberry and strawberry seeds not a problem and we add a good spoonful of flax seeds as well...still smooth...if you have some whey protein or something you wish to add, that would work beautifully too I am sure of it.  I found frozen peaches at Target for the reviewer that couldn't find them...guess I just assumed they'd be at at any grocery store.  I always have bananas around so those go in fresh (heavily speckled if you wish for added sweetness) and the rest frozen as a last minute treat/breakfast...the frozen fruit is not difficult for the Vita Mix and I enjoy the more frozen texture of the finished product.  My kids can't get enough of this treat and I love when I see them enjoying something so much that is so good for them.

The shake was easy to put togther the night before and I just used my blender at home the following morning (which is great since I'm NOT a morning person and dont' have time to cook a full breakfast during weekdays).  It is a large portion, but I drank it over the course of 2 hours as I was getting ready for work, driving to work and finished it that morning. (and although 350-400 calrories, it's still less than my usual muffin in the morning and much healthier).  It tastes great although the seeds can be a tad annoying but the fact that I didn't feel sluggish and wasn't starving by lunch makes this my new breakfast food.  Hope to see more episodes like this in the future!
Excellent smoothie. Anyone know how many calories are in there?

This is an excellent smoothie, I made it exactly as Alton suggested except 4 the peaches, haven't found them yet.  next time I will add a touch of honey, but otherwise I luv this.  Some thought it was a lot to consume but the serving was perfect for me, may be due to the missing peaches.  I will have this everyday it is soooooo healthy and tasty!!  My cheap blender made it a challenge but well worth it.
YUM!  Half the recipe is perfect for me, with skim milk since I love dairy.  My old  variable speed blender does a fine job.  I haven't had a blueberry in years!  YUM!

The texture was far smoother than I thought it would be (based on previous smoothie attempts). It was actually luscious.

The flavors come together really well and get me eating blueberries which are healthy as all-get-out; I just otherwise can't stand them.

I couldn't find straight-up Acai, but found a Northwoods blend with blueberry and blackberry juise (most of the blend is apple, let's face it).

This smoothie is BIG, very satisfying. I did a quick estimate of the calories, thinking this was a "smoothie for two" but was happy to see that the total isn't that big.

For weight loss, keeping my hunger in check is the biggest challenge, and this recipe will help.

Follow Alton's directions exactly (except the expensive blender, just be kind to your cheap one and go slow) and you will achieve the perfect smoothie, no alterations necessary. It's sweet, healthy, delicious, and most importantly of all....purple.
This smoothie was very easy to make and came out so amazing. Sweet and healthy.

video.name: Buff Smoothie
video.description: Alton's here to give you a new appreciation of the humble smoothie.
